Highlights

  • Workday Completes Acquisition of Sana (2025-11-04): Workday concluded its purchase of Sana this week, enhancing its platform's AI-driven knowledge and learning solutions. Sana’s expertise in AI-powered enterprise search positions Workday at the forefront of agentic, context-rich assistance. This acquisition will let Deloitte bring smarter knowledge orchestration to client projects, laying the groundwork for upskilling and hyper-personalized talent experiences at scale.
  • Workday Recognized as a 2025 Inc. Power Partner Award Winner (2025-11-05): Workday received the Inc. Power Partner award, reflecting enterprise confidence not just in HCM/ERP foundations, but also new AI-driven innovations. This third-party endorsement enhances Deloitte’s ability to credibly promote Workday-based transformations, reassuring cautious buyers and CFOs of platform stability in the era of rapid AI change.
  • Bain: Agentic AI as the Inflection Point for ERP Transformation (2025-11-01): Bain’s new report frames agentic AI as central to scalable, future-proof ERP strategies. Their analysis differentiates between truly modular agentic ecosystems (exemplified by recent Workday moves) and more restrictive automation toolkits. Deloitte teams should adapt their methodologies to highlight agentic process redesign, ensuring clients see measurable value while navigating change risk.
  • EY: Governance for Agentic AI Systems (2025-11-01): EY outlined essential risk management for agentic AI, calling for transparency, ongoing impact assessment, and operational controls in SaaS HCM/ERP contexts. This focus dovetails with Workday’s governance advances and sets expectations GSIs like Deloitte must meet to assure risk-averse, heavily regulated clients.
  • Microsoft Named a Leader in AI-Enabled ERP by IDC (2025-11-04): Microsoft achieved industry leadership recognition for its Copilot-powered agentic AI. Their focus on context-aware, embedded intelligence mirrors and challenges Workday’s recent strategy.
  • KPMG: Board-Level Priorities for Agentic Corporate Services (Nov 2025): KPMG’s latest report urges organizations to view agentic transformation as a C-suite imperative, demanding operational, workforce, and governance redesign. This validates approaches Deloitte’s Workday advisors should emphasize in executive discussions.
  • CIO.com: The Agentic AI Revolution Is Now (2025-11-01): CIO.com’s in-depth feature puts the spotlight on disruptive, self-directed enterprise AI. Best-in-class SaaS adoption increasingly requires change management and human-centered enablement—both core to Deloitte’s value add.

What changed this week

This week marks a decisive shift from incremental AI augmentation toward platform-scale, agentic intelligence in SaaS ecosystems. Three factors stand out. First, Workday’s Sana acquisition is not simply feature enhancement but a bid to make knowledge-powered agentic AI foundational to operating models, driving value for both organizations and users through contextual, actionable insights. Second, consistent recognition from advisory, analyst, and press sources—whether in the form of third-party awards or leadership quadrants—validates that the operationalization of agentic AI, not just marketing, is what sways enterprise buyers.
Furthermore, governance has moved to the forefront. EY’s and KPMG’s board-level calls to action are reframing GSIs' consulting pitches from technical implementation to operational resilience and ethical assurance. Bain, meanwhile, underscores that agentic AI is setting a new competitive baseline for ERP transformation—one that not only increases enterprise velocity but also increases expectations for demonstrable business value at every step.
Cross-vendor momentum is significant: Microsoft’s recognition for Dynamics 365 Copilot, SAP’s advances in AI modularity and data partnerships, and KPMG’s and EY’s GSI playbooks signal the ecosystem is rapidly professionalizing. The implication for Deloitte's Workday team is clear: value, trust, and risk underwrite every client conversation. The week’s pattern is that advisory skill, platform fluency, and the capacity to drive empathic, context-driven AI transformation will separate the top performers from the rest in the coming quarter.

Competitive Watch

  • Microsoft: Leader in AI-enabled ERP (IDC, 2025-11-04). Microsoft’s Copilot strategy prioritizes enterprise-wide engagement with agentic AI, upping the ante for competitive user adoption and context-sensitive process automation. For Deloitte, this reinforces the need for cross-platform strength and proof-of-value delivery.
  • KPMG: C-suite imperatives for agentic AI. New guidance pushes governance and control topics to the top of enterprise transformation agendas. It amplifies the pressure on Deloitte’s teams to provide quantifiable assurance, risk management, and operating models tuned for agentic deployments.
  • SAP: Ecosystem partnerships and agentic AI enablement continue to expand SAP’s competitive position, requiring Deloitte practitioners to advise clients on orchestrating best-of-breed hybrid SaaS stacks and harmonizing data for agentic value creation.
  • EY: Governance-first approach for agentic SaaS deployments. EY is strengthening its reputation as a safe pair of hands for regulated, risk-mature enterprises, which Deloitte must match with robust, actionable controls and compliance accelerators for Workday AI rollouts.

Enablement

  • AI Adoption Change Management: Preparing your workforce for AI agents (CIO). Master the step-wise deployment of agentic AI—balancing operational efficiency with user acceptance and transformation longevity.
  • Agentic AI Governance Frameworks: EY’s agentic AI risk management guidance. Enable teams to integrate governance up front, ensuring platforms like Workday are audit-ready and resilient at scale.
  • Client Value Storytelling: Bain’s ERP agentic AI report. Equip advisors with frameworks and business case evidence to lead clients through measurable, agentic transformation.

Actions for Next Week

  • Roll out enablement on new Workday/Sana capabilities; highlight cross-client value cases in knowledge orchestration and learning.
  • Update all governance playbooks with the latest EY and KPMG agentic AI expectations and integrate into client delivery templates.
  • Create quick-reference guides comparing agentic AI maturity and ecosystem strengths across Workday, Microsoft, and SAP for client-facing use.
  • Engage client sponsors to showcase Workday’s latest recognition and discuss how Deloitte accelerates business outcomes with new agentic features.

Risks & Mitigations

  • Governance uncertainty may stall adoption: Counter by demonstrating robust, transparent, and continuously audited agentic AI models based on latest GSI and vendor guidance.
  • Platform expertise gaps could erode Deloitte’s trusted advisor status: Rapid upskilling and practice-aligned collateral for agentic SaaS ecosystems are essential to retain and grow account leadership.
  • User resistance amid transformation intensity: Lead with empathic change management, continuous stakeholder engagement, and role-based enablement built into every agentic deployment.

All Sources

  • Workday Completes Acquisition of Sana - Nov 4, 2025
  • Workday Recognized as a 2025 Inc. Power Partner Award Winner
  • Is Agentic AI the Inflection Point for Scaling ERP Transformations
  • Harnessing agentic AI for effective risk management
  • Microsoft named a Leader in IDC MarketScape for AI-enabled Large Enterprise ERP Applications
  • KPMG agentic corporate services – Fifth edition November 2025
  • The agentic AI revolution: Why your business is about to get disrupted
  • Preparing your workforce for AI agents: A change management guide

Include:
- Workday AI advancements, partnerships, and feature releases.
- Competitive moves across major HCM/ERP vendors.
- GSI and boutique consultancy thought leadership, whitepapers, or partnership news.

- Regulatory, governance, or ethical AI considerations impacting enterprise HR systems.
- Patterns across vendor ecosystems and how they reshape client conversations.

- Create an **executive-grade synthesis (1200–1500 words)** with deep analysis and contextual insights.
- Each cited source should be summarized in **2–3 paragraphs**, explaining:
  - The essence of the update.
  - The implications for Workday and broader SaaS players.
  - The impact on Deloitte’s Workday practice, offerings, or positioning.
- Include a <h3>“What changed this week”</h3> section synthesizing shifts and sentiment.
- Highlight interconnections among Workday, competitors, GSIs, and boutiques.
- Include quantified insights or examples where possible.
- Do not fabricate; rely strictly on the SOURCE LIST URLs.

- Return JSON only (no Markdown or prose outside the object).
- `html_body` must use semantic HTML (<h2>, <h3>, <p>, <ul>, <li>, <a href="...">) with absolute URLs.

- `plain_text_body` = clean text summary with URLs visible.

Return JSON ONLY in this exact shape (no code fences, no extra text):

{
  "type": "daily or weekly",
  "run_date": "YYYY-MM-DD",
  "title": "Short headline",
  "priority_focus": "1–2 sentences on what matters most now",
  "highlights": [
    { "headline": "…", "why_it_matters": "…", "source_url": "https://…" }
  ],
  "competitive_watch": [
    { "competitor": "Name", "move": "…", "implication": "…" }
  ],
  "enablement": [
    { "skill": "Topic", "resource_url": "https://…", "90_day_outcome": "…" }
  ],
  "actions_next_week": ["…"],
  "risks": [
    { "risk": "…", "mitigation": "…" }
  ],
  "sources": [
    { "title": "…", "url": "https://…" }
  ],
  "html_body": "<h2>…</h2> (well-formatted HTML with <a href="https://…">links</a>; no scripts/external CSS)",
  "plain_text_body": "Text-only with visible URLs"
}

Parameters:
- Set "run_date" to TODAY_ET = 2025-11-08.
- For DAILY: set "type":"daily"; target ~1000 words; STRICTLY restrict to the last 24 hours (from 2025-11-07T08:00 to 2025-11-08T08:00); include publication dates in highlight text.
- For WEEKLY: set "type":"weekly"; target 2000–2500 words; restrict to 2025-11-01…2025-11-08; include <h3>What changed this week</h3> and publication dates in highlight text.
- Section order for html_body: Highlights; Competitive Watch; Enablement; Actions for Next Week; Risks & Mitigations; All Sources.
- Every item must include at least one absolute URL (https://…).
- Keep total HTML under ~25KB.

ADDITIONAL REQUIREMENTS
- For every highlight and competitive_watch item, include a 2–3 paragraph detailed summary within the "why_it_matters" text.
- Where relevant, compare perspectives across multiple sources.
- Include a clear "so what" statement for Deloitte’s Workday practice.
- Ensure all cited URLs appear in the `sources` array and inside the `html_body` link text.
- Keep factual accuracy and avoid speculation.
Raw OpenAI response JSON

It is especially relevant for procurement and HR audiences seeking credible, risk-mitigated partners for large-scale transformation.\",\n      \"source_url\": \"https://newsroom.workday.com/2025-11-05-Workday-Recognized-as-a-2025-Inc-Power-Partner-Award-Winner\"\n    },\n    {\n      \"headline\": \"Bain: Agentic AI at the Inflection Point for ERP Transformation (2025-11-01)\",\n      \"why_it_matters\": \"Bain’s latest analysis argues agentic AI is now the chief catalyst for scaling ERP transformation. The report describes how AI agents move beyond basic automation, driving self-orchestration and freeing teams for higher-value work—a key differentiator in platform selection. Bain notes that the competitive field is quickly separating into vendors that provide modular, interoperable agentic AI (such as Workday post-Sana) and those with narrow, point-tool approaches. For Deloitte’s Workday advisors, Bain’s framework brings a sense of urgency: clients will expect proof of real-world agentic outcomes, and even established governance processes must evolve to support new, adaptive AI behaviors. Deloitte practitioners should prioritize frameworks that help clients realize agentic process redesign while controlling risks in global deployment.\",\n      \"source_url\": \"https://www.bain.com/insights/is-agentic-ai-the-inflection-point-for-scaling-ERP-transformations\"\n    },\n    {\n      \"headline\": \"EY: AI Governance Is a Top Priority as Agentic Systems Proliferate (2025-11-01)\",\n      \"why_it_matters\": \"EY’s global guidance spotlights a growing need for strong AI governance as agentic systems become more autonomous in enterprise processes. EY presents practical risk management actions (operational transparency, ongoing impact assessment) for organizations integrating agentic AI into HR and finance workflows. This aligns with Workday’s recent platform investments and efforts to embed governance in AI feature rollouts. For the SaaS market, effective AI governance is not simply a compliance requirement; it is increasingly becoming a core differentiator. Deloitte’s Workday teams should accelerate client conversations on AI accountability models and auditability, leveraging both Workday and Deloitte frameworks.\",\n      \"source_url\": \"https://www.ey.com/en_gl/insights/financial-services/emeia/what-risk-leaders-need-to-do-now-about-agentic-ai\"\n    },\n    {\n      \"headline\": \"Microsoft Named a Leader in AI-Enabled ERP by IDC (2025-11-04)\",\n      \"why_it_matters\": \"On November 4, IDC recognized Microsoft as a leader in AI-enabled large-enterprise ERP. Notably, Microsoft’s messaging focuses on seamless end-user engagement with AI—mirroring Workday’s own shift. This model of agentic orchestration—linking HCM, finance, and beyond—closely resembles Workday’s long-term vision. Deloitte’s Workday consultants should anticipate executive-level scrutiny and tie proposals to quantifiable business results, governance, and emergent workforce models.\",\n      \"source_url\": \"https://assets.kpmg.com/content/dam/kpmg/lu/pdf/kpmg_boardroom_considerations_brochure_2025.pdf\"\n    },\n    {\n      \"headline\": \"CIO.com: Agentic AI Is the Next Big Disruptor (2025-11-01)\",\n      \"why_it_matters\": \"CIO.com’s investigation into the agentic AI revolution (published November 1, 2025) calls out the transformative disruption about to hit enterprises: self-directed AI agents will reframe how SaaS platforms are built, selected, and governed. Workday’s recent moves and public messaging by leading GSIs like Deloitte are tightly aligned to these trends. Sana’s expertise in AI-powered enterprise search positions Workday at the forefront of agentic, context-rich assistance. This acquisition will let Deloitte bring smarter knowledge orchestration to client projects, laying the groundwork for upskilling and hyper-personalized talent experiences at scale.</li>\\n<li><strong>Workday Recognized as a 2025 Inc. Power Partner Award Winner (2025-11-05):</strong> <a href=\\\"https://newsroom.workday.com/2025-11-05-Workday-Recognized-as-a-2025-Inc-Power-Partner-Award-Winner\\\">Workday received the Inc. Power Partner award</a>, reflecting enterprise confidence not just in HCM/ERP foundations, but also new AI-driven innovations. This third-party endorsement enhances Deloitte’s ability to credibly promote Workday-based transformations, reassuring cautious buyers and CFOs of platform stability in the era of rapid AI change.</li>\\n<li><strong>Bain: Agentic AI as the Inflection Point for ERP Transformation (2025-11-01):</strong> <a href=\\\"https://www.bain.com/insights/is-agentic-ai-the-inflection-point-for-scaling-ERP-transformations\\\">Bain’s new report</a> frames agentic AI as central to scalable, future-proof ERP strategies. Their analysis differentiates between truly modular agentic ecosystems (exemplified by recent Workday moves) and more restrictive automation toolkits. Deloitte teams should adapt their methodologies to highlight agentic process redesign, ensuring clients see measurable value while navigating change risk.</li>\\n<li><strong>EY: Governance for Agentic AI Systems (2025-11-01):</strong> <a href=\\\"https://www.ey.com/en_gl/insights/financial-services/emeia/what-risk-leaders-need-to-do-now-about-agentic-ai\\\">EY outlined essential risk management for agentic AI</a>, calling for transparency, ongoing impact assessment, and operational controls in SaaS HCM/ERP contexts. This focus dovetails with Workday’s governance advances and sets expectations GSIs like Deloitte must meet to assure risk-averse, heavily regulated clients.</li>\\n<li><strong>Microsoft Named a Leader in AI-Enabled ERP by IDC (2025-11-04):</strong> <a href=\\\"https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics-365/blog/business-leader/2025/11/04/microsoft-named-a-leader-in-idc-marketscape-for-ai-enabled-large-enterprise-erp-applications\\\">Microsoft achieved industry leadership recognition</a> for its Copilot-powered agentic AI. Their focus on context-aware, embedded intelligence mirrors and challenges Workday’s recent strategy.</li>\\n<li><strong>KPMG: Board-Level Priorities for Agentic Corporate Services (Nov 2025):</strong> <a href=\\\"https://assets.kpmg.com/content/dam/kpmg/lu/pdf/kpmg_boardroom_considerations_brochure_2025.pdf\\\">KPMG’s latest report</a> urges organizations to view agentic transformation as a C-suite imperative, demanding operational, workforce, and governance redesign. This validates approaches Deloitte’s Workday advisors should emphasize in executive discussions.</li>\\n<li><strong>CIO.com: The Agentic AI Revolution Is Now (2025-11-01):</strong> <a href=\\\"https://www.cio.com/article/4085161/the-agentic-ai-revolution-why-your-business-is-about-to-get-disrupted-whether-you-like-it-or-not.html\\\">CIO.com’s in-depth feature</a> puts the spotlight on disruptive, self-directed enterprise AI. Best-in-class SaaS adoption increasingly requires change management and human-centered enablement—both core to Deloitte’s value add.</li>\\n</ul>\\n<h3>What changed this week</h3>\\n<p>This week marks a decisive shift from incremental AI augmentation toward platform-scale, agentic intelligence in SaaS ecosystems. Three factors stand out. First, Workday’s Sana acquisition is not simply feature enhancement but a bid to make knowledge-powered agentic AI foundational to operating models, driving value for both organizations and users through contextual, actionable insights. Second, consistent recognition from advisory, analyst, and press sources—whether in the form of third-party awards or leadership quadrants—validates that the operationalization of agentic AI, not just marketing, is what sways enterprise buyers.<br/>\\nFurthermore, governance has moved to the forefront. EY’s and KPMG’s board-level calls to action are reframing GSIs' consulting pitches from technical implementation to operational resilience and ethical assurance. Bain, meanwhile, underscores that agentic AI is setting a new competitive baseline for ERP transformation—one that not only increases enterprise velocity but also increases expectations for demonstrable business value at every step.<br/>\\nCross-vendor momentum is significant: Microsoft’s recognition for Dynamics 365 Copilot, SAP’s advances in AI modularity and data partnerships, and KPMG’s and EY’s GSI playbooks signal the ecosystem is rapidly professionalizing. The implication for Deloitte's Workday team is clear: value, trust, and risk underwrite every client conversation. The week’s pattern is that advisory skill, platform fluency, and the capacity to drive empathic, context-driven AI transformation will separate the top performers from the rest in the coming quarter.</p>\\n<h2>Competitive Watch</h2>\\n<ul>\\n<li><strong>Microsoft:</strong> <a href=\\\"https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics-365/blog/business-leader/2025/11/04/microsoft-named-a-leader-in-idc-marketscape-for-ai-enabled-large-enterprise-erp-applications\\\">Leader in AI-enabled ERP (IDC, 2025-11-04)</a>. Microsoft’s Copilot strategy prioritizes enterprise-wide engagement with agentic AI, upping the ante for competitive user adoption and context-sensitive process automation. For Deloitte, this reinforces the need for cross-platform strength and proof-of-value delivery.</li>\\n<li><strong>KPMG:</strong> <a href=\\\"https://assets.kpmg.com/content/dam/kpmg/lu/pdf/kpmg_boardroom_considerations_brochure_2025.pdf\\\">C-suite imperatives for agentic AI</a>. New guidance pushes governance and control topics to the top of enterprise transformation agendas. It amplifies the pressure on Deloitte’s teams to provide quantifiable assurance, risk management, and operating models tuned for agentic deployments.</li>\\n<li><strong>SAP:</strong> Ecosystem partnerships and agentic AI enablement continue to expand SAP’s competitive position, requiring Deloitte practitioners to advise clients on orchestrating best-of-breed hybrid SaaS stacks and harmonizing data for agentic value creation.</li>\\n<li><strong>EY:</strong> <a href=\\\"https://www.ey.com/en_gl/insights/financial-services/emeia/what-risk-leaders-need-to-do-now-about-agentic-ai\\\">Governance-first approach for agentic SaaS deployments</a>. EY is strengthening its reputation as a safe pair of hands for regulated, risk-mature enterprises, which Deloitte must match with robust, actionable controls and compliance accelerators for Workday AI rollouts.</li>\\n</ul>\\n<h2>Enablement</h2>\\n<ul>\\n<li><strong>AI Adoption Change Management:</strong> <a href=\\\"https://www.cio.com/article/4082282/preparing-your-workforce-for-ai-agents-a-change-management-guide.html\\\">Preparing your workforce for AI agents (CIO)</a>. Master the step-wise deployment of agentic AI—balancing operational efficiency with user acceptance and transformation longevity.</li>\\n<li><strong>Agentic AI Governance Frameworks:</strong> <a href=\\\"https://www.ey.com/en_gl/insights/financial-services/emeia/what-risk-leaders-need-to-do-now-about-agentic-ai\\\">EY’s agentic AI risk management guidance</a>. Enable teams to integrate governance up front, ensuring platforms like Workday are audit-ready and resilient at scale.</li>\\n<li><strong>Client Value Storytelling:</strong> <a href=\\\"https://www.bain.com/insights/is-agentic-ai-the-inflection-point-for-scaling-ERP-transformations\\\">Bain’s ERP agentic AI report</a>. Equip advisors with frameworks and business case evidence to lead clients through measurable, agentic transformation.</li>\\n</ul>\\n<h2>Actions for Next Week</h2>\\n<ul>\\n<li>Roll out enablement on new Workday/Sana capabilities; highlight cross-client value cases in knowledge orchestration and learning.</li>\\n<li>Update all governance playbooks with the latest EY and KPMG agentic AI expectations and integrate into client delivery templates.</li>\\n<li>Create quick-reference guides comparing agentic AI maturity and ecosystem strengths across Workday, Microsoft, and SAP for client-facing use.</li>\\n<li>Engage client sponsors to showcase Workday’s latest recognition and discuss how Deloitte accelerates business outcomes with new agentic features.</li>\\n</ul>\\n<h2>Risks &amp; Mitigations</h2>\\n<ul>\\n<li><strong>Governance uncertainty may stall adoption:</strong> Counter by demonstrating robust, transparent, and continuously audited agentic AI models based on latest GSI and vendor guidance.</li>\\n<li><strong>Platform expertise gaps could erode Deloitte’s trusted advisor status:</strong> Rapid upskilling and practice-aligned collateral for agentic SaaS ecosystems are essential to retain and grow account leadership.</li>\\n<li><strong>User resistance amid transformation intensity:</strong> Lead with empathic change management, continuous stakeholder engagement, and role-based enablement built into every agentic deployment.</li>\\n</ul>\\n<h2>All Sources</h2>\\n<ul>\\n<li><a href=\\\"https://newsroom.workday.com/2025-11-04-Workday-Completes-Acquisition-of-Sana\\\">Workday Completes Acquisition of Sana - Nov 4, 2025</a></li>\\n<li><a href=\\\"https://newsroom.workday.com/2025-11-05-Workday-Recognized-as-a-2025-Inc-Power-Partner-Award-Winner\\\">Workday Recognized as a 2025 Inc. Deloitte can now accelerate knowledge-driven transformations with robust, context-aware upskilling tools.\\n\\n- Workday Recognized as a 2025 Inc. Power Partner Award Winner (2025-11-05): https://newsroom.workday.com/2025-11-05-Workday-Recognized-as-a-2025-Inc-Power-Partner-Award-Winner\\n  This award spotlights Workday’s high-performance, high-trust reputation among enterprises during a crucial period of AI innovation. Deloitte can use this recognition to reassure risk-aware clients and support platform selection decisions.\\n\\n- Bain: Agentic AI at the Inflection Point for ERP Transformation (2025-11-01): https://www.bain.com/insights/is-agentic-ai-the-inflection-point-for-scaling-ERP-transformations\\n  Bain highlights agentic AI as the main driver for scalable ERP transformation, separating vendors who provide modular, interoperable AI (Workday) from those with point solutions. For Deloitte, this frames agentic redesign as a necessity, not a luxury, for clients seeking real ROI.\\n\\n- EY: AI Governance Is a Top Priority as Agentic Systems Proliferate (2025-11-01): https://www.ey.com/en_gl/insights/financial-services/emeia/what-risk-leaders-need-to-do-now-about-agentic-ai\\n  EY urges organizations to strengthen AI governance, transparency, and operational risk management as agentic systems become core to SaaS. Deloitte must maintain deep fluency in both Workday and Microsoft environments.\\n\\n- KPMG: Board-Level Attention on Agentic Corporate Services (Nov 2025): https://assets.kpmg.com/content/dam/kpmg/lu/pdf/kpmg_boardroom_considerations_brochure_2025.pdf\\n  KPMG advised C-levels to view agentic AI as a top transformation priority, emphasizing the need for operational and governance change alongside platform rollout. This mirrors Workday’s vision and supports Deloitte’s strategy of quantifying value and risk resilience.\\n\\n- CIO.com: Agentic AI Is the Next Big Disruptor (2025-11-01): https://www.cio.com/article/4085161/the-agentic-ai-revolution-why-your-business-is-about-to-get-disrupted-whether-you-like-it-or-not.html\\n  CIO.com positioned agentic AI as the next wave of disruption, stressing the need for human-empowered change management. Deloitte should pivot conversations to include empathetic enablement and reskilling.\\n\\nWhat changed this week:\\n- Workday leads with a transformative acquisition, making agentic knowledge orchestration a key pillar for SaaS.\\n- Validation from awards and industry leadership quadrants reinforced that operational, not just marketing, advances in agentic AI will sway enterprise deals.\\n- Governance, transparent deployment, and risk management took a central role across analyst and GSI thought leadership.\\n- Cross-vendor moves (Microsoft, SAP, KPMG, EY) demonstrate the professionalization and rising expectations for agentic ecosystem orchestration.\\n- Deloitte must deliver integrated expertise, risk controls, and business-value realization to stay at the forefront of agentic SaaS transformation.\\n\\nCompetitive Watch:\\n- Microsoft: https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics-365/blog/business-leader/2025/11/04/microsoft-named-a-leader-in-idc-marketscape-for-ai-enabled-large-enterprise-erp-applications\\n- KPMG: https://assets.kpmg.com/content/dam/kpmg/lu/pdf/kpmg_boardroom_considerations_brochure_2025.pdf\\n- SAP: (SAP featured in ecosystem context; [...] AIOps — short for AI for IT operations — is an emerging operational practice that uses machine learning and automation to help organizations monitor, manage, and troubleshoot complex digital systems. Today, they streamline tasks and sharpen decisions. Tomorrow, they’ll reshape how functions like finance, HR and procurement are designed, overlaying human judgment onto machine precision. [...] That’s how a US-based gaming and entertainment company gained momentum. The company’s AI steering committee was energized about the potential of AI agents, but those who were less advanced in their understanding of the technology remained skeptical. KPMG teams worked with the company to pilot two targeted use cases: one to answer procurement policy queries and the other to flag anomalies in payables.       "url": "https://kpmg.com/kpmg-us/content/dam/kpmg/pdf/2025/ai-for-auditing.pdf",
      "title": "ai for auditing: 12 use cases to jumpstart your journey | 2",
      "content": "→ Where to begin Focus on specific problems you want to solve. Again, start small, focusing on one or two high-priority use cases. Work with your IT team to (1) understand in-house agentic AI technologies or potential technologies worth acquiring and (2) develop effective AI models. Data preparation is crucial — AI agents need clean, consistent, accurate, relevant data. [...] For example, you could kick off a payroll audit by querying a generative AI tool with a prompt like, “I’m preparing to audit the payroll process. I want to understand the types of things that can go wrong in the payroll process.” After the AI lists possible risks, you can iterate with different prompts to refine your list. From there, you can ask about typical controls associated with each risk, test procedures for each control, and required documentation to support test steps. You can even ask [...] AI agents can be quite sophisticated. Potential use cases are highly compelling: autonomous continuous risk monitoring, risk assessments, compliance checks, fraud detection, real-time decisions on prioritization or audit approaches (based on predefined parameters), scenario simulations, audit report generation, resource management, and stakeholder reporting.",

Why wait until the next disruptive event adds sudden pressure to abandon the traditional “job” construct? \n\n#### Moving on, with clarity and purpose [...] Finally, there’s a whole host of vendors offering SBO-specific solutions; it’s encouraging that you can now implement a common and integrated suite of tools to spotlight where new skills are needed, monitor existing skills, match skill supply to demand, and develop organizational and talent capabilities. This capability lets you introduce more complicated logic to your query.\n\nThis syntax is supported in Rules, Search, and Dashboards.\n\n## Syntax\n\n```\nif(BOOL_CLAUSE, THEN_CLAUSE, ELSE_CLAUSE) \n```\n\n## Nested `if` examples\n\n### Search example: outcome section\n\nThis example assigns an outcome score based on `principal.hostname`.       "title": "Leading people through AI change",
      "content": "Be transparent in plain language about what AI is used for, the data involved, how this will impact people and teams, and how to challenge a decision. That’s how you keep your social licence.\n\n##### Measure change - performance and value - beyond speed [...] Wellbeing cues: watch signals (after-hours activity, leave not taken, sentiment dips) and act early.\n Micro-wins & acknowledgement: celebrate small improvements; name the people who improve safety, equity and clarity — not just speed.\n Crisis playbook: pre-agree who communicates what if something goes wrong; model calm, fact-based updates. [...] Predictable cadence: short, regular updates — what we tried, what we learned, what’s next. Certainty of rhythm reduces anxiety.\n Protected learning time: book recurring practice blocks (e.g., 2 hours a fortnight). Learning happens in daylight, not after hours.\n Pairing & peer support: buddy early adopters with peers; rotate “AI pair” weeks to spread confidence.\n Load management: timebox reviews, batch approvals, and pause low-value work to create capacity.",

Raw Tavily response JSON
{
  "query": "NIST AI RMF HR use cases",
  "follow_up_questions": null,
  "answer": null,
  "images": [],
  "results": [
    {
      "url": "https://kpmg.com/kpmg-us/content/dam/kpmg/pdf/2025/ai-for-auditing.pdf",
      "title": "ai for auditing: 12 use cases to jumpstart your journey | 2",
      "content": "→ For better results Get specific. For instance, in your payroll audit, maybe you’d like to understand certain data patterns or anomalies that may indicate payroll fraud and noncompliance (e.g., overpayments/underpayments, unusual deductions). You could ask the AI to suggest predictive analytics methods for using relevant historical data (e.g., average salaries based on position, payroll budgets) to predict and forecast future payroll trends, which can help identify outliers. [...] For example, you could kick off a payroll audit by querying a generative AI tool with a prompt like, “I’m preparing to audit the payroll process. I want to understand the types of things that can go wrong in the payroll process.” After the AI lists possible risks, you can iterate with different prompts to refine your list. From there, you can ask about typical controls associated with each risk, test procedures for each control, and required documentation to support test steps. You can even ask [...] Fortunately, as outlined in previous use cases, generative AI tools excel at tasks that require comparing and synthesizing information across multiple disparate information sources, making them a great fit for project staffing. For example, in AuditBoard AI’s intelligent staffing feature, managers define which skills and qualifications are important, add them to team members’ profiles, and indicate which skills and qualifications are needed for each new project. Then, AuditBoard AI combines",
      "score": 0.42663267,

      "content": "codes that complement the act are expected. History The AI Act is the outcome of a process aimed at regulating the use and supply of AI systems in the EU. The process involved several communications (2018, 2019, 2021, and 2024), parliamentary resolutions, a white paper and a parliamentary report. The Commission published the proposal for an AI regulation in 2021. The proposal suggested a risk-based approach differentiating between 'unacceptable' risks, 'high-risk', and 'limited risk'. The [...] extend into 2026, and that the Commission might consider temporary solutions to address the delays. [...] (blog) Implementation steps The regulation entered into force in 2024, with a general date of application of 2 August 2026, which includes the enforcement rules (Chapter 9). However, several chapters, sections and articles have other dates of application. As a result, and in its current state, the AI Act should be fully effective by 2027. To facilitate its implementation, several publications are expected during the implementation process. For instance, Article 96 requests the European",

      "url": "https://newsroom.workday.com/2025-11-05-Workday-Recognized-as-a-2025-Inc-Power-Partner-Award-Winner",
      "title": "Workday Recognized as a 2025 Inc. Power Partner Award ...",
      "content": "Workday is the enterprise AI platform for managing people, money, and agents. Workday unifies HR and Finance on one intelligent platform with AI at the core to empower people at every level with the clarity, confidence, and insights they need to adapt quickly, make better decisions, and deliver outcomes that matter. Workday is used by more than 11,000 organizations around the world and across industries – from medium-sized businesses to more than 65% of the Fortune 500. For more information [...] Pleasanton, Calif., Nov. 5, 2025 — Workday, Inc. (NASDAQ: WDAY), the enterprise AI platform for managing people, money, and agents, today announced that it has been named to the Inc. Power Partner Awards list. This marks the second consecutive year Workday has been recognized on this prestigious list, which honors B2B organizations that have proven track records supporting entrepreneurs and helping small and midsize organizations grow. [...] Workday is dedicated to making its best-in-class, AI-powered platform accessible and impactful for organizations of nearly any size.       "title": "Fail Fast to Win Big: Rethinking the path to AI Success in ...",
      "content": "We’ve helped organisations set up AI development platforms that give AI teams a head start by providing pre-approved, secure environments for rapid prototyping, with access to the right tools, data, and controls, without the setup overheads. This kind of infrastructure investment pays for itself in velocity. \n\nIt’s more likely that an AI project will fail because it doesn’t work for users, not because it didn’t scale for production. Start small, test early, learn fast. [...] Instead, we’ve helped organisations adopt a Deployed AI Team model: where the centralised AI group temporarily embed smaller sub-teams in business units for use-case specific solution development. \n\nWhen this works well, it unlocks: \n\nBut challenges can occur with this model when business users don’t feel ownership of the project. This can result in limited user engagement as it’s seen as “side of desk” activity, and projects running on despite not showing value because: [...] Data availability and quality should be top-tier criteria, not just at kick-off, but throughout the project lifecycle. Treat every promising use case as a data problem first, AI problem second. If it’s not clear what the real data is going to look like, where it’s going to come from, or when it’s going to be available, that’s a sign to pause. \n\n### Bridging the Gap: Deployed AI Teams",

      "content": "Within the derived AI strategy, data and technology capabilities (the tech foundation) play a central role alongside strategy, people, and processes. These investments in technology provide the foundation to enable [...] True value and differentiation can be achieved when AI deployment is directly derived from corporate strategy and treated as a holistic transformation effort. At the same time, organisations must have a realistic view on how such transformations unfold: progress is not linear but also not random. The key is to actively manage individual phases — consciously tolerating temporary productivity declines and higher investment needs. Through clear strategic priorities, visible quick wins, and the [...] However, the real potential of AI, namely, to create substantial value and sustainable differentiation, will only be fully realised when AI is no longer seen as a collection of single use cases, but as an integrated part of the strategic orientation and management of the company, supported by a closely aligned AI investment and implementation roadmap.",

    {
      "url": "https://kpmg.com/xx/en/what-we-do/alliances/oracle/building-a-pragmatic-framework-for-scalable-and-trusted-ai.html",
      "title": "Building a pragmatic framework for scalable and trusted AI",
      "content": "## From automation’s limits to augmentation’s potential\n\nThe first wave of generative AI centered on automation: machines replacing repetitive or rule-based tasks. It delivered efficiency gains — a finance team saves hours by automating reconciling processes, an HR team lightens its administrative load. Many of these wins were siloed. The broader function, let alone the enterprise, didn’t fundamentally change. [...] The impact was immediate. Employees who had been weighed down by repetitive tasks saw relief, trust in the technology grew — and most importantly — the quick wins sparked a pipeline of new ideas to use AI agents across the business.\n\n> AI is moving so fast that it’s hard for organizations to keep up. We help break it down, so clients can take the first steps. The key is not to be apprehensive. Instead, start small, lean on trusted advisors and build momentum from there.\n\nNick Yoko [...] Executives today want (and need) more. They want augmentation: AI that enables human performance, is embedded directly into workflows, and can evolve business models and ecosystems — all to uplift human potential and foster lasting value.",
      "score": 0.21437915,
      "raw_content": null

You have to keep reminding people that applying technology to a broken business process just makes the broken process move faster.       "content": "On paper, AI promises sweeping transformations — automating full functions, radically reducing costs and accelerating decisions. In practice, the current reality is more nuanced. While AI has advanced considerably, delivering sophisticated generative, predictive and analytical capabilities, its most widely adopted applications often focus on task-level enhancements: drafting performance goals, writing first-pass job postings, or summarizing call notes. These contributions, though undeniably [...] helpful, highlight a persistent gap between AI’s transformative potential and tangible, widespread organizational impact. This discrepancy leaves executives navigating three pressing hurdles: [...] Bias, security gaps and misaligned decisions are real risks. Responsible use policies, monitoring frameworks and transparency protocols build trust in both the technology and its outcomes.\n ###### Move in sprints\n\n  Incremental rollouts with human checkpoints make progress tangible, mitigate risks and build confidence at each stage.\n ###### Co-evolve with the platform",

      "content": "As we went through the outsourcing craze of the ’90s and early 2000s, many internal technology functions atrophied their technology muscles, because all you needed to do was to buy SAP, Workday, and Veeva, and you were good to go. With what’s happening with technology, you have to become builders again. [...] I also think a lot about stuff that’s not technical in nature. A lot of times there’s a combinatorial effect between changing process and changing technology or using data, and there’s still a bias that AI is a magic bullet. You have to keep reminding people that applying technology to a broken business process just makes the broken process move faster. It’s important to remember the basics, such as ensuring your roles and responsibilities and incentive systems people are right, and then also [...] So many projects, particularly technology projects at big companies, follow a waterfall effect of spending considerable time scoping. They then do a statement of work and a request for proposals with third parties, and then they are locked into constraints of how long the project can be, how much it can cost, and who they can use as their partner. Today, they streamline tasks and sharpen decisions. Tomorrow, they’ll reshape how functions like finance, HR and procurement are designed, overlaying human judgment onto machine precision. [...] ## From automation’s limits to augmentation’s potential\n\nThe first wave of generative AI centered on automation: machines replacing repetitive or rule-based tasks. It delivered efficiency gains — a finance team saves hours by automating reconciling processes, an HR team lightens its administrative load. Many of these wins were siloed. The broader function, let alone the enterprise, didn’t fundamentally change. [...] Executives today want (and need) more. They want augmentation: AI that enables human performance, is embedded directly into workflows, and can evolve business models and ecosystems — all to uplift human potential and foster lasting value.",

      "url": "https://www.sap.com/products/artificial-intelligence/ai-assistant.html",
      "title": "Joule Copilot from SAP | Artificial Intelligence",
      "content": ":   Joule uses generative AI to respond to the intent of user questions and requests expressed in natural language. Joule determines how to respond by combining the user’s intent with rich context about their business role and the SAP applications and data that run business processes. Joule uses skills and collaborative AI agents to complete tasks, reveal insights, and autonomously perform multistep workflows using generative AI. [...] :   An AI copilot is a virtual assistant that uses a conversational interface to help users of business applications complete tasks more efficiently. Copilots use generative AI and other technologies to understand user requests, perform actions, and provide insights based on business data. Compared to earlier digital assistants, AI copilots provide a more human-like conversational experience and a broader and more flexible range of capabilities. Omnissa Horizon® provides solutions for virtual desktops and apps, digital employee experience, and robust security—all underpinned by AI-driven automation. [...] As the Omnissa UEM Engineering team began migrating the production workloads at scale, it observed a few challenges such as latency issues and failures during RDS instance up-sizing, user databases becoming stuck in a SUSPECT state, database restore errors, and high memory usage during peak transaction workloads. The application exhibited distinct usage patterns, with peak activity occurring at the start of the workday when users began logging in. [...] Omnissa, formerly the VMware End-User Computing business, is a digital workspace technology leader that delivers smart, seamless, and secure digital work experiences for organizations worldwide.     {
      "title": "\"workday\" or \"work day\" | WordReference Forums",
      "url": "https://forum.wordreference.com/threads/workday-or-work-day.2945218/",
      "content": "Workday (noun) = (i) days upon which most people work, e.g. \"Next Monday is a public holiday, but Tuesday will be a normal workday. (ii) days upon which specific people work, e.g. \"Saturday and Sunday are normal workdays for policemen.\"  \n (i) adjective relating to days upon which most people work, e.g. \"Today, she would not go anywhere special, so she put on her workday clothes.\"  \n   \n  more commonly \"working day\". [...] To me (BE) there are 3 words:  \n   \n \"Workaday\" (adjective) = mundane; common; usual; standard (of quality); \"The new cell phone is not remarkable at all, it has a workaday processor and last year's screen.\" (Often used in the phrase \"[in the] workaday world of high finance/professional football/aviation/teaching, etc, etc.\" meaning 'normal and not exciting area of activity') [...] You are using an out of date browser. It may not display this or other websites correctly.  \nYou should upgrade or use an alternative browser.\n\n# \"workday\" or \"work day\"\n\n Thread starter w3lifer\n Start date\n\n#### w3lifer\n\n##### New Member\n\nPlanet Earth\n\nRussian, Belorussian\n\n #1\n\nHello.  \n What is the difference between \"workday\" and \"work day\"?  \n Why do some people write \"workday\", others — \"work day\"?\n\n#### KHS\n\n##### Senior Member\n\nCharlotte, North Carolina, USA\n\nUSA - English L1\n\n #2",
      "score": 0.16130732,
      "raw_content": null
    },
    {
      "title": "Difference between \"working days\" and \"weekdays\"",
      "url": "https://forum.wordreference.com/threads/difference-between-working-days-and-weekdays.2566775/",
      "content": "* Rules/Help/FAQ Help/FAQ * Members Log in Register How to install the app on iOS Follow along with the video below to see how to install our site as a web app on your home screen. ##### Member (In the examples like \"the centre is open on working days/ weekdays\") ##### Senior Member Yes, weekdays are the days from Monday to Friday, as opposed to the weekend. This is the usual expression if you mean those five days. We'd talk about working days only if there was a possibility of them being different - so 'working days' excludes public holidays. ##### Member Thank you very much, your explanation was very helpful You must log in or register to reply here.",

I would not say \"on the workday\" here (nor can I imagine using it at any other time).  \n   \n \"On workdays or in the their leisure time\" is poor (although each phrase on its own is fine). Most workers get several hours leisure time even on workdays, before and after work.\n\n#### Kacy.H\n\n##### Senior Member\n\nChina\n\nChinese\n\n #3\n\n> Uncle Jack said:\n>\n> several hours leisure time\n>\n> Click to expand...",

      "url": "https://forum.wordreference.com/threads/seeking-vs-to-seek.4076594/",
      "content": "Rules/Help/FAQ\n Members\n Interface Language\n\n English Only\n English Only\n\n# seeking vs. to seek\n\n Thread starter\n  如沐春风\n Start date\n\n#### 如沐春风\n\n##### Senior Member\n\nChinese\n\n #1\n\n> In May 1886, US activists organized a national strike seeking an eight-hour workday. (from：www.cnn.com › travel › article）\n>\n> Click to expand... [...] a national strike which was seeking an eight-hour workday  \n  \nAnother assumption is that the non-finite clause is what's left of a prepositional phrase, in which case it's an adverbial clause:  \n  \na national strike because they were seeking an eight-hour workday [...] By demonstrating, they are seeking to obtain something. Their goal is to obtain, not to seek to obtain.  \n  \nI realise I am nit-picking here.\n\nM\n\n#### manfy\n\n##### Senior Member\n\nSingapore\n\nGerman - Austria\n\n #11\n\nI agree with veli.   \nWhen you compare these (expanded) sentences directly, they just \"feel\" so different;  \n\nUS activists organized a national strike because they were seeking an eight-hour workday.​\n\nUS activists organized a national strike in order to seek an eight-hour workday.​",

      "url": "https://forum.wordreference.com/threads/todays-evening.1854213/",
      "content": "I'm sorry, but I don't understand what you're saying: \"tonight\" means not evening. Could you rephrase this? Tonight can refer to any time after a person leaves work, on a regular workday. You are welcome to use evening, in which case, you'd say this evening. Either one is perfectly fine and commonly used.\n\nA\n\n#### Adam Cruge\n\n##### Banned\n\nIndia & Bengali\n\n #5\n\nOh thank you.       "url": "https://kpmg.com/kpmg-us/content/dam/kpmg/pdf/2025/ai-for-auditing.pdf",
      "title": "ai for auditing: 12 use cases to jumpstart your journey | 2",
      "content": "Anton Dam Vice President, Data - AI/ML AuditBoard Anton Dam is the Vice President of Engineering for Data, AI/ML at AuditBoard. In his role, Anton is responsible for the development and deployment of artificial intelligence and machine learning technologies to enhance audit, risk, and compliance workflows. His experience includes developing enterprise AI products at LinkedIn and Workday, as well as at startups such as Restless Bandit and Skupos. [...] 12 Several enterprise technologies (e.g., Workday, Oracle HCM Cloud, SAP SuccessFactors, ADP Workforce Now, Ceridian Dayforce, Cornerstone OnDemand, AuditBoard AI) offer workforce planning features. To determine which solution is the right fit for your team’s needs, focus on if/how each technology can help you address the problems you want to solve. [...] Many quality assurance and improvement program (QAIP) tasks are a good fit for AI-enabled reviews. For example, when an audit is complete, Charles’ team uploads the workpapers to a SharePoint site, enabling him to interact with the documents via generative AI. Charles then works through his QAIP checklist by typing in prompts that enable him to gain reasonable assurance that the QAIP process is being performed and documented correctly.",

      "content": "free up resources to focus on the projects that come out on top. [...] Rather than stubbornly resist the often reported AI project failure statistics, organisations should embrace them and adapt their strategy to find value despite the high failure rate. If up to 95% of AI projects are going to fail across a portfolio then failure isn’t a risk, it’s almost a certainty. The risk is in allowing those projects to carry on when they could have been stopped earlier. Therefore the goal should be to fail on purpose, early and cheaply.By failing early and cheaply, you [...] Instead, we’ve helped organisations adopt a Deployed AI Team model: where the centralised AI group temporarily embed smaller sub-teams in business units for use-case specific solution development. \n\nWhen this works well, it unlocks: \n\nBut challenges can occur with this model when business users don’t feel ownership of the project. The key is to actively manage individual phases — consciously tolerating temporary productivity declines and higher investment needs. Through clear strategic priorities, visible quick wins, and the [...] AI is being driven by major technology companies, investing billions of dollars into the new technologies, and AI consequently continues to evolve rapidly. After large language models (LLMs), the next evolutionary stage, Agentic AI, is already on the horizon. Companies have to rethink their approach and their business strategies, and ask the right questions to successfully integrate AI into their core value creation processes. [...] To reach a higher level of AI maturity, organisations must be willing to tolerate productivity losses in the short-to-medium term and invest deliberately in AI foundations.     {
      "url": "https://www.pwc.com/us/en/industries/consumer-markets/library/retail-invisible-focus-group.html",
      "title": "Retail's invisible focus group: Testing strategy before it hits ...",
      "content": "A grocery retailer evaluating a protein-packed frozen meal promotion doesn’t have to rely on guesswork. With advances in AI, “synthetic customers” can provide reliable proxies on how real people shop—and explain their decisions in clear, conversational terms. [...] These aren’t static dashboards. They’re AI agents you can engage directly—designed to simulate how real customers think, choose, and change.\n\nExecutives can ask questions like: Would this discount increase a shopper’s basket size? Could swapping this product trigger unexpected churn? Where should I launch this new product? And instead of just outputting probabilities, synthetic customers can respond with AI-enabled logic in natural language, linking expected behaviors to motivations. [...] For example, in response to the promotion detailed above, a persona modeled on a millennial GLP-1 user might say: “At that price, I’d buy three meals and freeze them,” an indication of the pantry effect. Another, representing Gen Z parents, might push back: “My kids won’t eat the store brand—the discount doesn’t matter,” potentially leaving the brand or the category.",

Avestan sadra- \"grief, sorrow, calamity,\" Greek kedos \"care, trouble, sorrow,\" Welsh cas \"pain, anger\"). Related: Hated; hating. French haine (n.), hair (v.) are Germanic.     {
      "title": "Opposite of HATE – 35 Antonyms With Sentence Examples",
      "url": "https://www.applied-grammar.com/opposite-of-hate/",
      "content": "READ:  Opposite of FIRMLY - 35 Antonyms With Sentence Examples\n\nFinal Thoughts about Antonyms of HATE [...] Skip to content\n\nApplied Grammar by Gail Brubaker\n\n# Opposite of HATE – 35 Antonyms With Sentence Examples\n\nby Gail-Brubaker\n\nWhen exploring language, it is essential to understand antonyms. Antonyms are words that have opposite meanings from one another. They provide balance and contrast in written and spoken communication. By knowing antonyms for common words like hate, we can better express ourselves and convey nuanced emotions effectively. [...] By practicing empathy, forgiveness, and appreciation, we can overcome hate and create a more compassionate world. Choosing to replace negative emotions with their antonyms empowers us to see the good in others, build bridges instead of walls, and promote a culture of respect and unity. Embracing love and understanding enables us to break free from the cycle of hostility and build a brighter and more peaceful future for ourselves and those around us.\n\n### Related",
      "score": 0.011815436,
      "raw_content": null
    }
  ],
  "response_time": 8.79,
  "request_id": "d68a1e71-dc7b-4bcc-a7e6-9358e6ede6c6"

      "content": "The most effective organizations use a “three lines of defense” model: the first line builds and operates responsibly, the second reviews and governs, and the third provides periodic assessment and audit. That structure allows companies to move quickly while still maintaining confidence and control.\n\nHow are AI technologies, especially AI agents, reshaping Responsible AI? [...] Jennifer Kosar:The next big shift is already underway. The majority of leaders surveyed expect AI agents to reshape governance within the next year – both as a challenge and an opportunity. As systems become more autonomous, organizations are adapting oversight frameworks to include built-in testing, real-time monitoring, and automated controls. [...] We’re also seeing a shift in focus. Organizations aren’t just signing up to RAI principles, they’re asking how to make them real as the volume of AI deployments increases and agent deployments become reality. Half of respondents told us their biggest hurdle is turning those principles into practice by scaling and automating governance, clarifying roles and responsibilities, and aligning leadership around a consistent approach.\n\nWhat's holding companies back from scaling Responsible AI?",
